content.value: Networking in Linux means connecting your system to other devices, networks, or the internet using IP addresses and communication tools.
Every device that connects to a network receives an IP address. DNS helps convert website names to IPs, and HTTP/HTTPS are the rules (protocols) used for web communication.

value: Unique address of a device on a network (like a home address)
Phone book of the internet; converts domain names to IPs
Protocol used for web communication (not secure / port 80)
Connects your network to the internet or other networks

content.value: If internet fails: Check IP → Gateway → DNS → HTTP/HTTPS connection.

content.description: Shows network interfaces and assigned IP addresses.
Shows status of Wi-Fi/Ethernet network devices.
Shows open ports and active network services (e.g., web servers).

content.value: Use netstat to check if a service is running or if a port is open.
These tools help check network connection, DNS issues, and HTTP/website accessibility.

content.description: Checks if you can reach internet via DNS name.
Checks if network works without DNS (direct IP).
Check if domain name is resolving to an IP.
Requests a webpage from a server; great for testing websites & APIs.
Shows hop-by-hop path to a server; useful for slow/blocked network routes.

content.value: If ping works but curl doesn’t → website/server might be down, not your internet.

content.question: Which command tests if a website is responding?
Which command shows open ports and running network services?
If DNS is broken, which command will still work?

content.value: curl = web check | netstat = ports check | ping = connection check
